title: AstraZeneca unveils successes in treatment of lung cancer
keywords: ['Non-small cell lung cancer', 'Lung cancer', 'Progression delay', 'Clinical trial', 'the Financial Times', 'Tagrisso']
content_summary: The Tagrisso drug, which is the best-selling treatment for non-small cell lung cancer, has been shown to slow the progression of the disease in its early stages. This is significant because it provides hope for patients who are diagnosed at an early stage and want to delay the progression of the disease. The drug's effectiveness was demonstrated in a clinical trial, and the results were published in the Financial Times.

title: My productivity app is a never-ending .txt file (2022)
content_summary: The author found that they needed to get organized in college, as they couldn't rely on their memory alone to keep track of tasks and appointments. They tried various productivity apps and systems but found them discouraging, so they started tracking everything in a single text file. This system has been essential to their work for 14 years now and has scaled with their growing responsibilities. The author uses an online calendar as well to keep all future plans together, and every night they append the items on their calendar for the next day to the end of the text file as a daily todo list.

title: Big media publishers are inundating the web with subpar product recommendations
content_summary: Google regularly updates its algorithm to improve search results quality, but this can lead to a select group of big media publishers consistently ranking at the top of search results for specific product categories. These publishers often make recommendations without firsthand testing and simply paraphrase marketing materials and Amazon listing information, rather than providing independent and useful reviews. Despite waiting patiently for algorithm updates to impact these results, small sites like HouseFresh have seen little improvement in their rankings.

title: Jeff Dean: Trends in Machine Learning [video]
content_summary: The speaker will discuss current trends in artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML), including enhanced algorithms and significant advancements in various areas. These improvements are driving innovation and expanding the applications of AI/ML, such as natural language processing, computer vision, and autonomous systems. The speaker will highlight these developments and their potential impact on various industries and society as a whole.

title: I broke IKEA (2023)
content_summary: In a recent phone call, I received an automated message from an unknown number claiming to be from IKEA. The message requested that I press 1 to continue in English. However, I suspected it might be a spam call and so I pressed ### (the # key by itself) to hang up immediately. This resulted in a rapid sequence of DTMF tones, known as a "DTMF bomb," which blew up the spammer's PBX. The call ended with a burst of digital static.

title: WebKit switching to Skia for 2d graphics rendering
content_summary: The WebKit team has been working to improve graphics performance in their GTK and WPE ports, resulting in features like threaded rendering, DMA-BUF renderer, and proper VSync. However, they have reached the limits of what can be achieved with a CPU-based 2D renderer, leading them to explore other options. They tried using Cairo but found it difficult to retarget and had slow corner cases. They then decided to write their own GPU rendering library, which initially showed impressive results in performance. However, they struggled to find the right balance between performance and rendering quality, so they put the development on hold. Their next option is Skia, which they did not consider initially due to lack of a public library with API stability that distros can package. Now that they have more experience maintaining third-party dependencies, they are willing to give Skia a try internally to see if it's worth the effort of maintaining it as a third-party module.

title: Translating OpenStreetMap data to HTML5 Canvas with Rust and WebAssembly
content_summary: The author is using the Overpass API to retrieve OpenStreetMap data and then processing it in Rust to create a simplified 3D map. They are avoiding using any JavaScript libraries for this first experiment, instead using direct CSS and JavaScript edits to an HTML page. The author chose to use Rust and WebAssembly for data processing due to its performance capabilities when handling large amounts of coordinates.

title: In Defense of Simple Architectures (2022)
content_summary: Wave, a $1.7 billion company with 70 engineers, has a CRUD app architecture that is based on a standard monolithic structure using Python and Postgres. Despite being a large company, the engineering team focuses on delivering value to users, which has allowed them to scale efficiently. The company's website ranks in the top 75,000 according to Alexa, while traffic is relatively low due to being a mobile app. However, the unreasonable effectiveness of simple architectures has led to most press and conferences focusing on complex architectures, such as microservice-based systems, rather than monolithic structures.

title: Cve-rs: Fast memory vulnerabilities, written in safe Rust
content_summary: Blazingly fast and secure memory vulnerability detection has been achieved through the use of 100% safe Rust programming language. Special thanks to contributors from the cve-rs community, with licensing under the GLWTSPL. The project aims to provide lightning-fast and reliable memory security testing without compromising on safety.

title: Web Scraping in Python – The Complete Guide
content_summary: BeautifulSoup is a library that enables developers to build robust web crawlers by providing lightning-fast parsing of XML and HTML data. It helps overcome scraping challenges and provides best practices for large-scale scraping. By leveraging BeautifulSoup, developers can efficiently parse and extract data from websites, overcoming common issues such as JavaScript rendering and CAPTCHAs.

title: Microsoft is spying on users of its AI tools
content_summary: Microsoft has announced that its AI tools have detected Chinese, Russian, and Iranian hackers using the technology to enhance their cyber operations. The company collaborated with OpenAI to share threat intelligence on these state-affiliated adversaries, who are using large language models (LLMs) to augment their cyber attacks. This revelation suggests that Microsoft and potentially other parties may be monitoring user activity on AI platforms like ChatGPT.

title: SSDs have become fast, except in the cloud
content_summary: AWS EC2 was a pioneer in offering NVMe instances, starting with the i3 instance in 2017. This instance featured 8 physically-attached NVMe SSDs, which was remarkable for its time as NVMe SSDs were still expensive. Since then, several NVMe instance types have been launched, but performance has not increased significantly, with the i3 and i3en instances remaining the best options for IO-bandwidth/$ and SSD-capacity$.

title: Let's Build the GPT Tokenizer [video]
keywords: ['Natural Language Processing (NLP)', 'LLM', 'Efficient Processing', 'Text Breaking Down', 'Tokenizer', 'Large Language Models (LLMs)', 'Large Language Models']
content_summary: The Tokenizer is a crucial component of Large Language Models (LLMs) that converts sequences of text into tokenized representations. This process involves breaking down the input text into smaller chunks or tokens, which are then used as inputs for the LLM's processing. The Tokenizer is necessary for efficient and accurate processing of natural language text, allowing LLMs to handle complex linguistic structures and generate coherent output.

title: Planner programming blows my mind
content_summary: Picat is a research language that combines logic programming, imperative programming, and constraint solving. It allows users to provide a set of equations and find assignments that satisfy those relationships, rather than writing algorithms to produce outputs. The planner module in Picat is one of the most fascinating programming models the author has seen, which can be used to solve complex problems such as vacation scheduling.

title: Keep your phone number private with Signal usernames
content_summary: Signal has introduced new features to further enhance privacy for its users. By default, phone numbers will no longer be visible to everyone in Signal, and users can create a unique username to initiate contact without sharing their phone number. Additionally, an optional privacy setting allows users to control who can find them on Signal by phone number. All of these features are available in the beta version of the app and will roll out to everyone in the coming weeks.

title: LED Matrix Earrings
content_summary: In a YouTube video, the creator shows off an LED stud earring design that is extremely cheap and features a tiny machined battery holder for two LR521 cells. The goal was to replace the plastic gemstone and single LED with their own circuit board, using the same metalwork. However, the challenge lies in shrinking the design by a factor of 3 while avoiding a thick border around the board, which makes routing tracks difficult. To give a sense of scale, three small 0201 LEDs are shown next to a regular surface mount LED, and an ATtiny85 is also shown with an 0201 LED on its back. The creator mentions that it's possible to get multilayer boards made with blind and buried vias, but these boards can be expensive, starting at several hundred dollars for a small batch. To keep the project under $50 total, the creator decided to craft their own circuit board sandwich by placing two two-layer boards together with an array of solder pads around the perimeter.

title: Kagi Sidekick (alpha)
content_summary: Follow @KagiHQ on Twitter for updates and join their Discord server to discuss.

title: If architects had to work like programmers (1995)
content_summary: At present, it is not possible to travel to other planets or galaxies due to the limitations of current technology. While there have been advancements in space exploration, such as the use of robotic probes and manned missions to the Moon, the vast distances between celestial bodies make interstellar travel impractical. Therefore, for now, it is not possible to visit other planets or galaxies outside of our own solar system.

title: Japan bets $67B to become a global chip powerhouse once again
ChatGPT went berserk
content_summary: OpenAI has acknowledged an issue with ChatGPT, where users are reporting various problems. Devin Morse, a philosophy PhD student, has collected more examples in a thread. OpenAI itself has stated that they don't know the cause or how long it will take to fix. Gary Marcus, a prominent AI researcher, emphasizes the need for trustworthy AI and highlights the limitations of current generative AI systems, which are prone to instability and lack transparency. He argues that we need different technologies that are more interpretable, maintainable, and debuggable in order to achieve truly intelligent machines.

title: Insecure vehicles should be banned, not security tools like the Flipper Zero
content_summary: The federal government's proposal to ban security research tools, such as the Flipper Zero, is misguided and will be counterproductive. These tools are essentially programmable radios that can be built using open-source or simple over-the-shelf components, making it impossible to enforce a ban. Security experts argue that prohibiting these tools will stifle the Canadian economy and fail to address the root issue of insecure products. Instead, democratizing security research tools can help manufacturers improve the safety of their products.

title: Gemma: New Open Models
content_summary: Gemma is a new family of lightweight, state-of-the-art open models developed by Google DeepMind and other teams across Google. These models are inspired by the Gemini models and share technical and infrastructure components, enabling them to achieve best-in-class performance for their size compared to other open models. Gemma is available worldwide starting today and is designed with Google's AI Principles at the forefront, ensuring safe and responsible use of the models.

title: iMessage with PQ3 Cryptographic Protocol
content_summary: Apple is introducing PQ3, a groundbreaking cryptographic protocol for iMessage that provides unparalleled security against both classical and quantum attacks. With compromise-resilient encryption and extensive defenses, PQ3 surpasses the security properties of all other widely deployed messaging apps. Apple has been continuously upgrading the cryptography of iMessage since its launch in 2011, with each update being formally verified by symbolic evaluation for maximum security assurances.

title: Useful Uses of cat
content_summary: In the text, the author discusses the importance of modularity in software design, as advocated by David Parnas in his paper "Designing Software for Ease of Extension and Contraction." The author explains that code changes should be isolated to avoid altering existing code, and instead, new functionality should be added by adding new code. This approach allows for easier extension and contraction of the software system without compromising its original design. The author highlights four classes of problems that arise when trying to make changes to a software system, with the second class being relevant to this discussion.

title: AI behavior guardrails should be public
The killer app of Gemini Pro 1.5 is using video as an input
content_summary: Google recently released Gemini Pro 1.5, an updated version of their AI model series. This new version has a token capacity of 1 million, which is significant compared to previous models like Claude 2.1 (200,000 tokens) and gpt-4-turbo (128,000 tokens). One exciting feature of Gemini Pro 1.5 is the ability to use video as an input, which the author has tested successfully by uploading a 7-second video of their bookshelf. The model was able to identify some of the books in the video, though it didn't get all of them due to factors like motion blur and partial obscuration. Despite these limitations, the author is impressed with the model's performance and potential for use cases involving video inputs.

title: Atuin – Magical shell history
content_summary: AtuinSearch is a tool that allows users to sync, search, and backup their shell history. With AtuinSearch, users can enjoy enhanced command line functionality through features like ctrl-r, and can also keep their history forever by backing it up. The tool provides detailed FAQs for users to make the most of its features.

title: Unexpected responses from ChatGPT: Incident Report
content_summary: On February 20, 2024, a bug was introduced in the optimization of the user experience for ChatGPT, resulting in nonsensical responses generated by the language model. The bug affected how the model processes language, causing inference kernels to produce incorrect results in certain GPU configurations. OpenAI identified and resolved the issue through a fix. Subscribe to updates for further notifications regarding any future incidents.

title: Things unexpectedly named after people (2020)
content_summary: The list of companies named after their founders or significant individuals is incomplete and frustratingly so. Some have suggested additional names, including Rocket Lab, which is not actually named after its founder Mark Rocket. Despite this, the list continues to circulate in 2024.

title: Private company landing on the moon today
keywords: ['Payloads', 'Columbia Shuttle Street', 'South Pole', 'Intuitive Machines', 'The Press Kit', 'Lunar mission', 'Technologies', 'LLC', 'TX']
content_summary: Intuitive Machines, LLC is offering a Press Kit for the IM-1 mission, which includes comprehensive details on the mission objectives, cutting-edge technologies used, and the significance of the payloads being delivered to the Moon's South Pole. The Press Kit can be accessed by contacting the company at 13467 Columbia Shuttle Street, Houston, TX 77059 or by submitting an email to get updates on new news stories.

title: Google to pause Gemini image generation of people after issues
keywords: ['Google', 'Gemini AI', 'Social media controversy', 'AI image generator', 'Historical accuracy', 'Racial representation']
content_summary: Google has acknowledged that its Gemini AI image generator has produced historically inaccurate results, with some depictions of white figures being altered to appear as people of color. The company has apologized and is working to improve the accuracy of these depictions. The controversy has been promoted by right-wing figures on social media, who have attacked Google's liberal reputation.

title: The Xylophone Maze: Screen-free coding for children
content_summary: A parent is looking for a screen-free, unplugged coding activity for their 3-year-old child. They consider building something from home materials instead of purchasing a separate toy. The parent stumbles upon the idea of creating a Lego maze and using an xylophone to play instructions for the child to help find their way through the maze, which can be played with minimal 2 players and adjusted for difficulty as the child grows older.

title: Cellular outage in U.S. hits AT&T, T-Mobile and Verizon users
content_summary: On Thursday, a cellular outage affected thousands of AT&T users in the United States, disrupting calls, text messages, and emergency services in major cities. The outage impacted both personal and business accounts, causing frustration for those trying to communicate or access essential services. No cause has been confirmed yet, but AT&T is working to resolve the issue as soon as possible.

title: Stable Diffusion 3
content_summary: Stable Diffusion 3 is an improved text-to-image model with enhanced performance in multi-subject prompts, image quality, and spelling abilities. The early preview phase is open for sign-ups, with a waitlist available to join. The model ranges from 800M to 8B parameters and combines a diffusion transformer architecture and flow matching, with a detailed technical report forthcoming. The team prioritizes safe and responsible AI practices, including safeguards against misuse, and continues to collaborate with experts and the community for innovation and integrity.

title: Show HN: Pages CMS – A CMS for GitHub
keywords: ['Free software', 'GitHub integration', 'Repository management', 'CMS', 'Open source', 'GitHub', 'Version control', 'Configuration file', 'User interface', 'Content management', 'Media management']
content_summary: In summary, Pages CMS is a free and open-source solution that allows users to manage content and media within their GitHub repository without having to install or deploy anything. It involves adding a single configuration file to the repository, which provides a user-friendly interface for managing content and media. The changes made through the CMS are tracked as regular commits on GitHub, providing version control and history of changes.

title: The Billion Row Challenge (1BRC) – Step-by-Step from 71s to 1.7s
content_summary: The Billion Row Challenge was a month-long competition where participants had to optimize a Parallel Java Streams implementation that took 71 seconds to run in just 1.7 seconds. The challenge was held on GitHub and encouraged contestants to share their ideas and learn from each other. Top Java performance experts, including Thomas Wuerthinger of the GraalVM project, submitted solutions that incorporated innovative techniques and ideas. My submission placed #9, while my QuestDB colleague Jaromir Hamala placed even higher on the leaderboard.

title: I turned my ThinkPad into a programmable USB device
keywords: ['IOSF', 'PSF', 'USB device emulation', 'Boot Guard', 'ACPI', 'BIOS/UEFI', 'P2SB', 'Linux kernel drivers', 'PMC', 'USB', 'TPM', 'Raw Gadget', 'PCH', 'NVRAM', 'UDC', 'Flexibility', 'xDCI', 'ThinkPad']
content_summary: The article describes the author's experience in enabling and using an xDCI controller on a ThinkPad X1 Carbon 6th Gen laptop to turn it into a programmable USB device. The author provides a detailed list of the steps involved, including fiddling with Linux kernel drivers, xHCI, DWC3, ACPI, BIOS/UEFI, Boot Guard, TPM, NVRAM, PCH, PMC, PSF, IOSF, and P2SB. The author also mentions using a custom USB cable to connect the laptop to an external UDC (USB Device Controller) for easier access to the Linux kernel USB Gadget subsystem. The article highlights the flexibility of Raw Gadget and UDCs in emulating USB devices and their potential use in fuzzing and exploiting USB hosts.

title: Bluesky announces data federation for self hosters
content_summary: The Bluesky network is opening up to allow users to host their own data, rather than having it stored by the social media company. This means that users can choose from various hosting providers or even host their data themselves, and can change their mind at any point without losing existing connections or posts. This allows for a more decentralized and interconnected network, similar to the internet itself.

title: JavaScript Bloat in 2024
content_summary: According to the text, the average size of JavaScript code downloaded per website is approximately 2.5KB. The author suggests that a simple experiment can be conducted by "fucking around and finding out" the exact size of the JavaScript code downloaded by a typical website. However, the author notes that booking a flight or hotel room through a website can be complicated due to the abundance of user interface (UI) elements.

title: Phind-70B: Closing the code quality gap with GPT-4 Turbo while running 4x faster
keywords: ['Natural language processing (NLP)', 'Computer programming', 'Code quality', 'Performance optimization', 'Machine learning (ML)']

title: Our Company Is Doing So Well That You're All Fired
content_summary: Paramount Global laid off around 800 employees a day after announcing record Super Bowl ratings. Despite the company's success, CEO Bob Iger announced the layoffs, citing the need to adapt to the latest evolution of capitalism. The company acknowledged that about 60% of the affected employees will be fine in the short term, but the rest may face uncertainty.

title: Nobody ever gets credit for fixing problems that never happened (2001) [pdf]
Show HN: Real-time image generation with SDXL Lightning
content_summary: Fal.ai has demonstrated a lightning-fast SDXL (Software Development eXperience Library) API using their AI technology. The demo showcases how the company's AI can quickly and efficiently develop software, surpassing human capabilities. Followers of the repo are encouraged to fork and build their own version of the AI-powered SDXL API.

title: Intuitive Machines successfully lands on the Moon
content_summary: The Odysseus spacecraft, built by Intuitive Machines, successfully landed on the surface of the moon after a 370,000 km journey. This is the first US moon landing since 1972 and the first time a commercial company has led a mission to the lunar surface. Confirmation of the landing came about 10 minutes after touchdown, with flight controllers excitedly announcing "We are on the surface!"

title: Vice website is shutting down
content_summary: The Vice website is shutting down, according to a tweet by Will Sommer. This news has come as a surprise to many, as Vice has been a prominent and influential media outlet for many years. The exact reason for the shutdown is not yet clear, but it is likely that financial difficulties or a decline in readership played a role.

title: Facial recognition error message on vending machine sparks concern at university
keywords: ['Facial recognition', 'Smart vending machines', 'the University of Waterloo', 'Surveillance', 'University campus', 'Privacy']
content_summary: A set of smart vending machines at the University of Waterloo is expected to be removed after students raised privacy concerns about their software. The machines have facial recognition technology and were selling chocolate and other candy throughout campus, including in the Modern Languages building and Hagey Hall. Students are covering a small hole on the machines that they believe houses a camera, and many are questioning why a university campus would install such technology without proper disclosure or consent.

title: Intel Processor Instability Causing Oodle Decompression Failures
keywords: ['BIOS', 'Unreal Engine', 'Oodle Data', 'RAD Game Tools', 'Intel', 'Intel processors', 'System instability', 'BIOS settings']
content_summary: RAD Game Tools has identified a hardware issue affecting certain Intel processors (13900K, 14900K, and possibly others) that can cause Oodle Data compression to fail or crash games built with Unreal Engine. The problem appears to be caused by a combination of BIOS settings and the high clock rates and power usage of these processors, leading to system instability and unpredictable behavior under heavy load. This issue is not due to any software bug in Oodle or Unreal, but rather overly optimistic BIOS settings that push the processors beyond their functional range. The problem can also affect other programs that heavily use the processor on many threads, leading to crashes or unpredictable behavior.

title: Thanks FedEx, this is why we keep getting phished
content_summary: According to the purchase confirmation email from Prusa, my order is scheduled to be shipped via FedEx and I can track the package on the FedEx website. To do this, I followed the link provided in the email and navigated to the FedEx tracking page, where I entered my tracking number to see the current status of my shipment.

title: Beyond A*: Better Planning with Transformers
content_summary: Transformers have made significant progress in various applications, but they still lag behind traditional symbolic planners when it comes to solving complex decision-making tasks. In this work, the authors propose Searchformer, a Transformer model that optimizes search dynamics for solving previously unseen Sokoban puzzles. They fine-tune the model through expert iterations to perform fewer search steps than $A^*$ search while still generating an optimal plan. The results show that Searchformer significantly outperforms baselines in terms of percentage of solved tasks and shortened search dynamics, and scales well to larger and more complex decision-making tasks.

title: Satoshi – Sirius emails 2009-2011
keywords: ['Satoshi Nakamoto', 'Private communication', 'Trial', 'Martti Malmi', 'Email correspondence', '@aalto.fi', 'the University of Helsinki']
content_summary: The correspondence between Martti Malmi (Sirius) and Satoshi Nakamoto reveals that they were in contact via email in 2011. Malmi decided to share the emails for an important trial in the UK in 2024, despite previously not being comfortable sharing private communication. The archive is incomplete and contains only emails sent from Malmi's address at the University of Helsinki, which has since changed to @aalto.fi.

title: Gemma.cpp: lightweight, standalone C++ inference engine for Gemma models
content_summary: Sure, here is a summary of the text in 3 sentences: The gemma.cpp project is a lightweight, standalone C++ inference engine for Google's Gemma models, which are designed for experimentation and research use cases. The engine targets CPU inference and takes advantage of portable SIMD provided by the Google Highway Library. The core implementation is approximately 2K LoC, with additional supporting utilities totaling around 4K LoC.

title: I Spent a Week with Gemini Pro 1.5–It's Fantastic
content_summary: In the article "Size Matters When it Comes to Context Windows," Dan Shipper discusses the significance of the size of the context window in artificial intelligence models, particularly in Google's new private beta LLM called Gemini Pro 1.5. The author notes that Gemini Pro 1.5's context window is significantly larger than previous models, allowing it to comfortably accept entire works of rationalist doomer fanfiction and even fit all of Eliezer Yudkowsky's 1,967-page opus Harry Potter and the Methods of Rationality into each message sent to Gemini. The author considers this a major achievement for two reasons: the larger context window enables Gemini Pro 1.5 to perform more complex tasks and accept longer inputs, and the model's ability to comfortably handle larger inputs is a significant improvement over previous models like GPT-4 Turbo, which can only accept a limited number of tokens.

title: Show HN: OK-Robot: open, modular home robot framework for pick-and-drop anywhere
content_summary: The project is not fully open source due to the closed-source license of one of its dependencies, AnyGrasp. Despite this limitation, the team used it as the best available option for grasping model access. The team would appreciate any feedback or thoughts on the project.

title: Meta's new LLM-based test generator
content_summary: Meta's TestGen-LLM is a tool that helps developers improve their productivity by generating code improvements using machine learning algorithms. It works by using an approach called "Assured LLM-based Software Engineering," which involves fine-tuning internal LLMs with Meta's own codebase to generate verifiable guarantees of improvement and non-regression. The tool offers tests for various software fundamentals, such as authentication, caching, databases, and API design, to help developers identify knowledge gaps and ensure they are on the right track both at work and during interviews.

title: Generative Models: What do they know? Do they know things? Let's find out
keywords: ['Image intrinsics', 'Depth perception', 'a Low-Rank Adaptation', 'INTRINSIC', 'Surface normals', 'Generative models', 'Scene reconstruction']
content_summary: Generative models, such as GANs and autoregressive models, are capable of producing highly detailed and realistic images. It is believed that these models learn to model image intrinsics, such as surface normals, depth, or shadows, implicitly. In this paper, the authors present evidence that generative models actually produce high-quality scene intrinsic maps internally. They introduce a universal approach called INTRINSIC LoRA (I-LoRA), which transforms any generative model into a scene intrinsic predictor without needing additional decoders or fully fine-tuning the original network. The method uses a Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) of key feature maps and has fewer than 0.6% of the total parameters in the original generative model.

title: A former Gizmodo writer changed name to 'Slackbot', stayed undetected for months
content_summary: Former Gizmodo writer Tom McKay managed to stay on the company's Slack workplace platform even after leaving by changing his name to "Slackbot." He went undetected for months by using a profile picture resembling the friendly robot icon and sending bot-like messages to his colleagues. The move allowed him to evade deletion of his account and continue participating in Slack conversations as a disguised former employee.

title: GPT in 500 Lines of SQL
content_summary: A large language model in SQL was implemented despite being told it's not suitable for doing so. The model takes a text string as input and returns an array of tuples, each containing a word and a probability number that indicates the likelihood of that word continuing the prompt.

title: Please make your table headings sticky
keywords: ['CSS', 'Responsive tables', 'Minimal CSS', 'Table structure', 'Screen size', 'Layout and appearance', 'Bootstrap or Foundation']
content_summary: To make tables responsive with minimal CSS, you can use the `table` and `td` elements along with the `colgroup` and `tbody` elements to define the structure of the table. You can then use CSS to style the table and its cells, using properties such as `width`, `height`, and `margin` to control the layout and appearance of the table on different screen sizes. Additionally, you can use CSS frameworks like Bootstrap or Foundation to quickly create responsive tables with pre-defined styles.

title: Power Metal: is it really about dragons? (2018)
content_summary: Matt Daniels wrote an article comparing the vocabulary of hip-hop artists to that of Shakespeare. Inspired by this, the author decided to analyze the lyrics of power metal bands to determine their use of certain words and themes. The dataset includes 58 bands and looks at the use of clean vocals, speed, and dragons in their music. The article aims to confirm or infirm the assumption that power metal bands often include lyrics about dragons in their songs.

title: Institutions try to preserve the problem to which they are the solution
content_summary: The Shirky principle states that institutions will try to preserve the problem they are meant to solve, even if it means hindering attempts by others to address the issue. This can be seen in examples such as tax-filing companies lobbying the government to prevent free and easy tax filing, private prison companies supporting policies that increase the number of incarcerated people, and a bus company petitioning to shut down a carpooling site because it works too well. The principle has important implications in various domains and it is important to understand its impact.

title: Google helped destroy adoption of RSS feeds (2023)
content_summary: Google has played a significant role in the decline of RSS feed adoption due to their behavior of exploiting the open web for their gain while ignoring user requests to restore RSS support. Early versions of Chromium had built-in RSS integration, but it was removed without notice. Additionally, Google acquired FeedBurner, an RSS feed service that replaces ordinary feeds with private ones owned by Google, modifying them to include advertisements and tracking mechanisms. These actions have contributed to the decline of RSS adoption and pose a threat to the freedom and openness of the internet.

title: Architecture.md (2021)
content_summary: The author suggests that maintaining an open-source project with a codebase between 10k and 200k lines of code should include an "ARCHITECTURE" document in addition to the README and CONTRIBUTING files. The author argues that this is not just another recommendation for better documentation, but rather a way to help new contributors quickly understand the project's physical architecture and save time when writing patches. The author shares their personal experience of feeling lost without a mental map of a codebase they are new to, and how an "ARCHITECTURE" file can help bridge this gap.

title: Earth just experienced its hottest 12 months in recorded history
content_summary: Sure, here is a summary of the text in 3 sentences: January 2023 broke temperature records worldwide, with several new heat records set during the month. According to multiple organizations, including NOAA and Copernicus, this was the hottest January on record, with temperatures above average across much of the globe. The past 12 months, from February 2023 to January 2024, were also the hottest consecutive 12-month period on record, with a temperature 0.64°C above the 1991-2020 average.

title: Hallucination is inevitable: An innate limitation of large language models
content_summary: In this paper, the authors formally prove that it is impossible to completely eliminate hallucination in large language models (LLMs) by defining a formal world where hallucination is defined as inconsistencies between a computable LLM and a computable ground truth function. They use results from learning theory to show that LLMs cannot learn all of the computable functions and will therefore always hallucinate, even in the real world. The authors also describe the hallucination-prone tasks for real-world LLMs and empirically validate their claims. Finally, they discuss possible mechanisms and efficacies of existing hallucination mitigators and the practical implications on the safe deployment of LLMs.

title: Marginalia: 3 Years
content_summary: Marginalia Search has improved significantly since its inception three years ago, with the search engine now working better than ever before. The codebase has been cleaned up and streamlined, making it more accessible to other developers and operators. Additionally, the search engine has achieved zero downtime upgrades and can now handle anchor text keywords more effectively, resulting in more relevant results. Despite these achievements, reaching 1 billion indexed documents remains an ongoing challenge.

title: Show HN: Reverse-Engineering a Switch Lite with 1,917 wires
content_summary: The author has developed a project that turns completed PCB assemblies into an easy-to-use boardview with accompanying boardscans. The goal is to do this as cheaply and with the highest quality possible, while minimizing errors. However, the author acknowledges that this may not be a viable business idea due to the high level of soldering skill required and the prevailing piracy culture. They are seeking feedback or alternative ideas for how to monetize their project.

title: Osquery: An sqlite3 virtual table exposing operating system data to SQL
Mamba Explained: The State Space Model Taking On Transformers
content_summary: The Mamba model is a new type of AI model called State Space Models (SSMs) that promises to be as powerful as Transformers but with faster inference and linear scaling in sequence length. The authors claim that Mamba enjoys fast inference and linear scaling in sequence length, and its performance improves on real data up to million-length sequences. Additionally, Mamba achieves state-of-the-art performance across several modalities such as language, audio, and genomics.

title: Coroutines in C (2000)
keywords: ['Processes and threads', 'Data production and consumption', 'Coroutines and concurrency', 'Program structure', 'Pipes and pipelining']
content_summary: The author discusses the difficulty of structuring large programs, particularly when it comes to producing and consuming data. They present two simple code fragments: one that produces characters through emit(), and another that consumes them through getchar(). The author suggests using pipes between processes or threads to connect the two fragments, allowing the output from the decompressor to feed directly into the parser. However, this solution can be heavyweight and non-portable. The author proposes a creative alternative: using coroutines to allow multiple functions to run concurrently, without the need for division into threads or processes.

title: Inside North Korea's Forced Labor Program
content_summary: According to a recent report by Ian Urbina, North Korean workers sent to Chinese factories endure beatings, sexual abuse, and have their wages taken by the state. These workers are told that if they try to escape, they will be "killed without a trace." The company, Donggang Jinhui Foodstuff, throws parties to celebrate its success, including performances by North Korean singers and dancers, and the use of North Korean flags and colors. Drone footage shows the company's twenty-one-acre compound, which includes processing and cold-storage facilities and a seven-floor dormitory for workers.

title: You are not late (2014)
keywords: ['Technological innovation', 'Entrepreneurship', "McDonald's", 'Domain names', 'Early internet history', 'Dot com names']
content_summary: In 1985, entrepreneurs had the opportunity to claim any dot com name they desired without cost. This was true for several years, with notable examples including mcdonalds.com and abc.com. However, when a Wired writer attempted to give mcdonalds.com to McDonald's, the company was clueless about the internet and their response became a story in Wired.

title: Home Screen Advantage
keywords: ['iOS restrictions', 'App market dominance', 'Apple', 'Web app functionality', 'User impact', 'Competition obstacles', 'EU']
content_summary: Apple's recent attempt to limit the functionality of Progressive Web Apps (PWAs) on iOS devices is seen as a ploy to maintain its dominant position in the app market. The company's proposal for "enabling" competing app stores is being criticized, and potential competitors are facing obstacles in entering the market. The impact of iOS 17.4 in the EU will be felt by schools, governments, startups, gamers, and other users who rely on web apps, as they may experience broken apps and lost data.
